contentrichtext.text: {{Redirect|Somnus|the thoroughbred racehorse|Somnus (horse)}} {{Other uses}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox deity | type = Greek | name = Hypnos | image = Waterhouse-sleep and his half-brother death-1874.jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = | caption = Hypnos and [[Thánatos]], ''Sleep and His Half-Brother Death'' by [[John William Waterhouse]] | god_of = God of [[Sleep]] | abode = [[Greek Underworld|Underworld]] | symbol = [[Poppy]] | consort = [[Pasithea]] | parents = [[Nyx (mythology)|Nyx]] | siblings = [[Thanatos|Thánatos]], [[Morpheus (mythology)|Morpheus]], [[Phobetor]] and [[Phantasos]] | children = [[Morpheus (mythology)|Morpheus]], [[Phobetor]] and [[Phantasos]] (according to Ovid) | mount = | Roman_equivalent = Somnus }} In [[Greek mythology]], '''Hypnos'''<ref name="theoi"/> ({{Lang-grc|Ὕπνος}}, "sleep") was the personification of sleep; the [[Roman mythology|Roman]] equivalent was known as '''Somnus'''.<ref name="theoi">[http://www.theoi.com/Daimon/Hypnos.html Theoi Project: Hypnos].</ref> His twin was [[Thánatos]] (Θάνατος, "death"); their mother was the primordial goddess [[Nyx]] (Νύξ, "night"). His palace was a dark cave where the sun never shone. At the entrance were a number of poppies and other [[hypnogogic]] plants. His dwelling had no door or gate so that he might not be awakened by the creaking of hinges. Hypnos' three sons or brothers represented things that occur in dreams (the [[Oneiroi]]). [[Morpheus (mythology)|Morpheus]], [[Phobetor]] and [[Phantasos]] appeared in the dreams of kings. According to one story, Hypnos lived in a cave underneath a [[Greece|Greek]] island; through this cave flowed [[Lethe]], the river of forgetfulness. [[Endymion (mythology)|Endymion]], sentenced by Zeus to eternal sleep, received the power to sleep with his eyes open. He was granted this by Hypnos in order to constantly watch his beloved [[Selene]], according to the poet, Licymnius Chios. Other stories <ref name="licymnius">[https://www.gaiaonline.com/guilds/viewtopic.php?t=20698427 Licymnius, Fragment 771 (from Athenaeus, Scholars at Dinner) (trans. Campbell, Vol. Greek Lyric V) (Greek lyric 4th century BC)]</ref><ref name="theoi">[http://www.theoi.com/Daimon/Hypnos.html Theoi]</ref> suggest, Hypnos fell in love with Endymion and granted him the power to sleep with his eyes open so Hypnos could watch Endymion without interruption. In art, Hypnos was portrayed as a naked youthful man, sometimes with a beard, and wings attached to his head. He is sometimes shown as a man asleep on a bed of feathers with black curtains about him. [[Morpheus (mythology)|Morpheus]] is his chief minister and prevents noises from waking him. In [[Sparta]], the image of Hypnos was always put near that of [[death]]. The English word "hypnosis" is derived from his name, referring to the fact that when hypnotized, a person is put into a sleep-like state (hypnos "sleep" + -osis "condition").<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/hypnosis?s=t Dictionary.com: Hypnosis].</ref> Additionally, the English word "insomnia" comes from the name of his Latin counterpart, Somnus. (in- "not" + somnus "sleep"),<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/insomnia?s=t Dictionary.com: Insomnia].</ref> as well as a few less-common words such as "somnolent", meaning sleepy or tending to cause sleep.<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/somnolent?s=t Dictionary.com: Somnolent].</ref> [[File:Hermes e Sarpedon.jpg|thumb|300px|Hypnos and [[Thanatos]] carrying dead [[Sarpedon]], while [[Hermes]] watches. Inscriptions in [[ancient Greek]]: HVPNOS-HERMES-θΑΝΑΤΟS (here written vice versa).
